elements.content: A bis-pyrrolide ligand containing a nonconjugated aromatic ring in the backbone was reacted with ThCl4(DME)2, affording the corresponding η6-{1,3-[(2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}ThCl3][Li(DME)3] (1) complex. In this species, the π-bonding interaction of the actinide with the ring is probably induced by steric constraint. The bonding mode of the pyrrolide rings was switched from σ to π upon treatment of complex 1 with Et3Al. This reaction was also accompanied by deprotonation of the aromatic ring and formation of two similar compounds with the ring σ-bonded to the Th metal center. The two compounds {[{1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}Th(μ-Cl-AlEt2)2](μ-Cl)2[{1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]C6H4}Th] (μ-AlEt2)Cl]}·(C7H8)0.5 (2a) and {[{1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}ThCl(μ-Cl)2[Li(DME)]2 (2b) were isolated and fully characterized. The common feature among these two species is that the switching of bonding mode of the pyrrolide rings, resulting from the coordination of the aluminum residues, is accompanied by deprotonation of the central ring. Attempts to reduce 1 yielded the paramagnetic [{η5-1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}ThK(μ-Cl)3][Li(DME)3] (3), which on the basis of the connectivity might be regarded as a rare case of Th(III). However, DFT calculation have elucidated the electronic structure of this species, which should be regarded as containing tetravalent Th bonded to the ligand radical anion. The spin density is mainly localized at the ring C atom, which is deformed and deviates from the planarity. Similar reductions carried out under slightly different reaction conditions afforded {η6-1,3-[(2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}Th{μ-η5-1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H5}K(DME)2 (4). In this complex the metal is surrounded by two ligands, one of which appears as having been partly hydrogenated at the central aromatic ring. Treatment of an in situ generated transient low-valent species with azobenzene as mild oxidizing agent resulted in reoxidation to a tetravalent thorium diphenylhydrazido species, [{η6-1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}Th(μ-η2-PhNNPh)(μ-Cl)(Cl)Li(DME)][Li(DME)3] (5).

elements.content:
Reduction of a tetravalent thorium complex afforded a paramagnetic reduced species or reoxidation at the expense of the reaction environment depending on the solvent employed.

Introduction

One of the primary characteristics of low-valent metals in unusual oxidation states is an outstanding reactivity encompassing several different aspects of molecular activation. Important breakthroughs in the chemistry of f-block elements during the last three decades clearly show that attempts to reach unstable oxidation states are often rewarded with the most unpredictable and diversified reactivity. A survey of the chemistry of strongly reducing low-valent samarium, neodymium, thulium, or uranium gives the immediate sense of an exceptional redox reactivity, the clearest indication being the frequent recurrence of dinitrogen activation.

Introduction

One of the primary characteristics of low-valent metals in unusual oxidation states is an outstanding reactivity encompassing several different aspects of molecular activation. Important breakthroughs in the chemistry of f-block elements during the last three decades clearly show that attempts to reach unstable oxidation states are often rewarded with the most unpredictable and diversified reactivity. A survey of the chemistry of strongly reducing low-valent samarium, neodymium, thulium, or uranium gives the immediate sense of an exceptional redox reactivity, the clearest indication being the frequent recurrence of dinitrogen activation.

elements.content: In the cases where the low-oxidation states cannot be obtained due to intrinsic instability, formation of reduced species may be a viable alternative. For the preparation of these species to be successful, the presence of a molecular unit capable of acting as electron storage is a key requirement. Systems containing delocalized π-electrons seem to be versatile for this purpose since a few f-block reduced complexes have been prepared in this manner. In some of these species, the metal may appear as low-valent, at least according to its connectivity. However, this appearance is deceiving since substantial electron density commonly resides in ligand-centered HOMOs with the metal being higher valent and the ligand in the form of a radical anion. What is truly remarkable in these complexes is that the chemical behavior remains what can be expected for genuine low-valent species, the ligand system clearly acting as electron storage. To account for these unique characteristics, the name “low-valent synthetic equivalents” has been forged.

elements.content: The behavior of thorium from this point of view might fall along the same lines. First, it should be noticed that low oxidation states are basically unknown for this element. There are only three cases of crystallographically authenticated reduced complexes of Cp and COT ligand systems. According to the connectivity of these paramagnetic complexes, the metal has the formal appearance of trivalent thorium. However, even the simple ThI2 is regarded not as a divalent thorium but as containing a higher-valent element with electrons stored in conduction bands generated by arrays of iodide anions. Therefore, is not impossible that even the very few existing cases of π-ligated Th(III) might in fact be low-valent synthetic equivalents rather than genuine low-valent thorium compounds. Attempts in the recent past to generate low-valent thorium species have afforded naphthalene π-complexes where the very visible distortion of the coordinated naphthalene ring doubtlessly indicated extensive reduction. As expected, the thorium atom maintained its more standard tetravalent state. Nonetheless, these species work as low-valent synthetic equivalents, producing transformations that can be rationalized as generated by authentic low-valent species as obtained from the dissociation of neutral naphthalene. When isolation of reduced species was not possible, generating highly reactive transient intermediates has also permitted molecular activation such as the sole example of thorium-promoted dinitrogen cleavage and partial hydrogenation. This unique transformation was possibly favored by an enhancement of radical activity of the reduced dinitrogen moiety capable of abstracting hydrogen atoms from the reaction environment.

elements.content: For the preparation of reduced thorium compounds we have now explored the possibility of using a dianionic ligand system where two pyrrolide anions are bonded in a nonconjugated fashion to one central phenyl ring. Pyrrolide anions have been shown to be versatile in the chemistry of divalent samarium and made their derivatives capable of surpassing the reducing power of samarocenes. Therefore, we expected that their coordination, either in σ- or π-fashion, might be instrumental to reactivity. The central ring was expected to be constrained at the bonding distance with the metal center and therefore providing a sort of π-interaction on demand. Such interaction was expected to assist the reductions and to favor the isolation of low-valent synthetic equivalents. We have now prepared the corresponding thorium complexes, studied their reduction chemistry, isolated a rare case of reduced compound, and obtained some indirect evidence about the ability of transient reduced species to embark on hydrogen abstraction reaction and reoxidation.

elements.content: All manipulations were performed under nitrogen atmosphere with rigorous exclusion of oxygen and water using standard Schlenk and glovebox techniques. Hexane, toluene, and THF solvents were purified by passing through Al2O3-filled columns and deoxygenated prior to use by several vacuum/nitrogen purges. DME was dried for 12 h over LiAlH4 and distilled under N2 prior to utilization. Benzene-d 6 and THF-d 8 were obtained from C/D/N Isotopes, dried over freshly activated molecular sieves (4 Å) for 10 days, and distilled under N2 atmosphere. Triethylaluminum solution in hexane was purchased from Aldrich and used as received. The ligand {1,3-bis-[1-(pyrrol-2-yl)-1,1-dimethyl]methyl}benzene was prepared according to the literature procedure. Complex ThCl4(DME)2 was prepared according to the literature procedure. NMR spectra were recorded at 293 K on a Varian Inova 500 MHz spectrometer. Chemical shifts were referenced to internal solvent resonances and reported in parts per million relative to TMS. Elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN analyzer. Data for X-ray single-crystal structure determination were collected with a Bruker diffractometer equipped with a 1K SMART CCD area detector.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Part

All manipulations were performed under nitrogen atmosphere with rigorous exclusion of oxygen and water using standard Schlenk and glovebox techniques. Hexane, toluene, and THF solvents were purified by passing through Al2O3-filled columns and deoxygenated prior to use by several vacuum/nitrogen purges. DME was dried for 12 h over LiAlH4 and distilled under N2 prior to utilization. Benzene-d 6 and THF-d 8 were obtained from C/D/N Isotopes, dried over freshly activated molecular sieves (4 Å) for 10 days, and distilled under N2 atmosphere. Triethylaluminum solution in hexane was purchased from Aldrich and used as received. The ligand {1,3-bis-[1-(pyrrol-2-yl)-1,1-dimethyl]methyl}benzene was prepared according to the literature procedure. Complex ThCl4(DME)2 was prepared according to the literature procedure. NMR spectra were recorded at 293 K on a Varian Inova 500 MHz spectrometer. Chemical shifts were referenced to internal solvent resonances and reported in parts per million relative to TMS. Elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN analyzer. Data for X-ray single-crystal structure determination were collected with a Bruker diffractometer equipped with a 1K SMART CCD area detector.

elements.content: A solution of 1,3-[(2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]C6H4 (5.00 g, 17.1 mmol) in Et2O (50 mL) was treated dropwise with a solution of MeLi in Et2O (1.6 M, 23 mL, 36.8 mmol). The sudden gas evolution terminated within 15 min from the end of the addition. Stirring was continued at room temperature for an additional 3 h. After that time the volume of the reaction mixture was reduced in vacuo to about 10 mL, and the resulting solution was layered with hexanes (30 mL). The colorless product was obtained as a microcrystalline material, which was separated by filtration, washed with hexanes (5 mL), and dried in vacuo for 6 h (5.19 g, 15.2 mmol, 89%). Anal. Found (calcd) for Li2C22H27N2O0.5: C 77.34 (77.41), H 7.87 (7.97), N 8.19 (8.21). 1H NMR (500 MHz, THF-d 8, 20 °C) δ: 7.92 (1H, ArH), 7.42 (3H, ArH), 7.37 (2H, pyrrole-H), 6.79 (2H, pyrrole-H), 6.36 (2H, pyrrole-H), 3.45 (2H, (CH3CH 2)2O), 1.88 (12H, −CH 3), 1.23 (3H, (CH 3CH2)2O).

elements.content: A solution of the ligand dilithium salt (0.45 g, 1.3 mmol) in DME (20 mL) was added to a suspension of ThCl4(DME)2 (0.37 g, 0.7 mmol) in DME (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h at room temperature and centrifuged to eliminate some insoluble material. The supernatant was concentrated to about 7 mL in vacuo, layered with hexanes (20 mL), and allowed to stand at room temperature for 2 days. Large pale yellow prisms of 1 separated from the solution and were collected and dried under N2 atmosphere (0.52 g, 0.6 mmol, 87%). Anal. Found (calcd) for ThLiC32H52Cl3N2O6: C 42.34 (42.42), H 5.67 (5.78), N 3.05 (3.09). 1H NMR (500 MHz, THF-d 8, 20 °C) δ: 8.05 (2H, ArH), 7.87 (1H, ArH), 7.77 (1H, ArH), 7.17 (2H, pyrrole-H), 5.72 (2H, pyrrole-H), 5.57 (2H, pyrrole-H), 3.39 (18H, DME, −O-CH 3), 3.22 (12H, DME, −CH 2-O), 1.65 (12H, −CH 3).

elements.content: A solution of AlEt3 (1.1 mL, 1.0 M, 1.1 mmol) in toluene was added dropwise to a suspension of complex 1 (0.20 g, 0.2 mmol) in the same solvent (10 mL). Stirring was continued at room temperature for an additional 6 h, and the insoluble material was separated by centrifugation. The volume of the supernatant was reduced to about 5 mL and allowed to stand at −37 °C for 3 days. Lemon yellow prisms of 2a separated, filtered, washed with cold (−37 °C) hexane (5 mL), and dried under N2 atmosphere (0.094 g, 0.06 mmol, 62%). Anal. Found (calcd) for Th2Al3C55.50H78Cl5N4 (2a): C 43.69 (43.75), H 5.01 (5.16), N 3.65 (3.68). 1H NMR (500 MHz, THF-d 8, 20 °C) δ: 7.31 (1H, Ar-H), 6.51 (2H, Ar-H), 6.30 (2H, pyrrole-H), 5.46 (2H, pyrrole-H), 5.26 (2H, pyrrole-H), 1.35 (12H, −CH 3), 1.01 (4H, Al-CH 2-CH3), 0.14 (6H, Al-CH2-CH 3).

elements.content: A suspension of 1 (0.62 g, 0.7 mmol) in DME (15 mL) was treated with a freshly prepared solution of K/naphthalene (0.06 g, 1.5 mmol of K with 0.19 g, 1.5 mmol of naphthalene) in the same solvent (10 mL). An immediate color change to dark red-brown was observed upon mixing, and stirring was continued for an additional 4 h at room temperature. Some insoluble material was separated by centrifugation, and the volume of the solution was reduced to about 5 mL by evaporation in vacuo. A slow discoloration of the solution was observed upon standing for 3 days at room temperature, which was accompanied by the appearance of pale pink prisms of 4. The crystalline mass was filtered, washed with hexane (5 mL), and dried under N2 (0.31 g, 0.30 mmol, 42%). Anal. elements.content: Computational Details. All DFT calculations were performed using the Gaussian 03 package using the B3LYP exchange−correlation functional and the SDD effective-core potential (ECP) basis sets. Tight SCF convergence criteria were used for all calculations. The converged wave functions were tested to confirm that they correspond to the ground-state surface. All calculations for the analysis of the electronic structure, including Mulliken population analysis and the calculation of Mayer two- and three-center bond order indices, atomic valences, and populations of fragment orbitals were performed using the AOMix software package.
elements.clean_text: Computational Details. All DFT calculations were performed using the Gaussian 03 package using the B3LYP exchange-correlation functional and the SDD effective-core potential (ECP) basis sets. Tight SCF convergence criteria were used for all calculations. The converged wave functions were tested to confirm that they correspond to the ground-state surface. All calculations for the analysis of the electronic structure, including Mulliken population analysis and the calculation of Mayer two- and three-center bond order indices, atomic valences, and populations of fragment orbitals were performed using the AOMix software package.

elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. For all the compounds, the results presented are the best of three data collection trials. The crystals were mounted on thin glass fibers using paraffin oil and cooled to the data collection temperature. Data were collected on a Bruker-AXS SMART 1k CCD diffractometer. Data for the compounds 1, 2a, 2b, 3, and 5 were collected with a sequence of 0.3° ω scans at 0°, 120°, and 240° in φ. To obtain acceptable redundancy data for compound 4, the sequence of 0.3° ω scans at 0°, 90°, 180°, and 270° in φ was implied. Initial unit cell parameters were determined from 60 data frames collected at the different sections of the Ewald sphere. Semiempirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied. Systematic absences in the diffraction data set and unit-cell parameters were consistent with monoclinic P21 /n for 1, monoclinic P21 /c for 5, orthorhombic Pbca for 2a, orthorhombic Pbcn for 2b, orthorhombic Pnma for 3, and triclinic P1̅ for 4. Solutions in centrosymmetric space groups for all of the compounds yielded chemically reasonable and computationally stable results of refinement. The structures were solved by direct methods, completed with difference Fourier synthesis, and refined with full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F 2. In structures of compounds 2b the Th metal center is located on a 2 rotation axis element of symmetry. In the structure of 3 a molecule of the complex resides on a mirror plane symmetry element. In structures of all the other compounds molecules of Th complexes are located in general positions. The structure of complex 3 represents a polymeric chain with monomers connected through bridging −Cl group coordination to the K metal center of the next monomeric unit. In this structure each monomeric unit is symmetry related to the next one through an n sliding plane symmetry operator. Carbon atoms of the cocrystallized toluene solvent molecule in 2 as well as carbon atoms of the DME solvent molecules coordinated to the Li cations in the structure of 5 were refined isotropicaly due to partial occupancy coupled with significant thermal motion disorder and in order to maintain an optimal data to parameters ratio. In all the structures, all non-hydrogen atoms, with the exceptions mentioned above, were refined with anisotropic displacement coefficients. All hydrogen atoms were treated as idealized contributions. All scattering factors are contained in several versions of the SHELXTL program library, version 6.12. Crystallographic data for all the structures are reported in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are available in the .

Crystal Structure Descriptions. 1. The crystal structure of 1 consists of an anionic Th-containing unit and an unconnected Li countercation solvated by three molecules of DME. The anionic fragment contains a Th metal center in a rather regular octahedral environment. One axial position of the coordination polyhedron is occupied by the centroid of the ligand phenyl ring engaged in a η6-bonding interaction with the Th atom [Th(1)−centroid(1) = 2.701(8) Å]. The second axial position contains one chlorine atom [Th(1)−Cl(1) = 2.661(2) Å, centroid(1)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 176.54(17)°] (Figure ). Two other chlorine atoms are located in two equatorial positions of the octahedron [Th(1)−Cl(2) = 2.698(2) Å, Th(1)−Cl(3) = 2.711(2) Å, Cl(2)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 86.21(7)°, Cl(3)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 86.85(7)°, Cl(2)−Th(1)−Cl(3) = 91.53(8)°]. Finally, the two remaining equatorial positions hold two nitrogen donor atoms of the two pyrrolyde moieties of the ligand system [Th(1)−N(1) = 2.436(7) Å, Th(1)−N(2) = 2.420(6) Å, N(1)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 90.81(16)°, N(2)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 90.80(15)°, N(1)−Th(1)−N(2) = 88.8(2)°, N(1)−Th(1)−Cl(2) = 90.39(16)°].

elements.content: 2a. The structure of 2a consists of two Th-containing units bridged by two chlorine atoms. The first contains the Th metal center in an octahedral environment. One axial position is occupied by a deprotonated carbon atom of the central phenyl ring of the ligand system [Th(1)−C(13) = 2.588(17) Å]. The second axial position is held by one terminal chlorine atom [Th(1)−Cl(3) = 2.751(4) Å, C(13)−Th(1)−Cl(3) = 176.9(4)°]. Two additional chlorine atoms are situated in the two equatorial positions [Th(1)−Cl(1) = 2.836(4) Å, Th(1)−Cl(2) = 2.834(4) Å, Cl(1)−Th(1)−Cl(3) = 87.11(13)°, Cl(2)−Th(1)−Cl(3) = 85.21(12)°, Cl(1)−Th(1)−Cl(2) = 68.96(11)°], providing the bridging interaction with the second Th-containing fragment [Th(1)−Cl(1)−Th(2) = 112.23(12)°, Th(1)−Cl(2)−Th(2) = 112.95(12)°] (Figure ). The two remaining equatorial positions around the first Th atom hold the centroids of the two pyrrolide rings of the ligand system with each ring being η5-coordinated to Th [Th(1)−centroid(1) = 2.636(14) Å, Th(1)−centroid(2) = 2.605(14) Å, centroid(1)−Th(1)−centroid(2) = 110.7(5)°, centroid(1)−Th(1)−Cl(3) = 99.0(5)°, centroid(2)−Th(1)−Cl(3) = 96.7(5)°, centroid(1)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 156.5(4)°]. The nitrogen atoms of these two pyrrolide rings are each σ-bonded to the Al atom of one Et2Al fragment [Al(1)−N(1) = 2.005(17) Å, Al(1)−N(2) = 2.003(14) Å, N(1)−Al(1)−N(2) = 95.7(5)°; Al(1)−C(41) = 1.94(2) Å, Al(1)−C(43) = 1.97(2) Å, C(41)−Al(1)−N(1) = 121.9(10)°, C(43)−Al(1)−N(2) = 95.7(5)°].

elements.content: The second Th atom of the second unit resides in the center of a pentagonal bipyramid, sharing two of the equatorial chlorine atoms with the first thorium-containing unit (Figure ) [Th(2)−Cl(1) = 2.964(4) Å, Th(2)−Cl(2) = 2.943(4) Å, Cl(1)−Th(2)−Cl(1) = 65.8(5)°]. Two other equatorial positions contain another two chlorines [Th(2)−Cl(4) = 2.965(4) Å, Th(2)−Cl(5) = 2.954(5) Å, Cl(4)−Th(2)−Cl(5) = 156.9(5)°, Cl(1)−Th(2)−Cl(5) = 134.5(4)°, Cl(2)−Th(2)−Cl(4) = 134.3(5)°], which are, in turn, involved in a bridging interaction with a second and third Al metal center [Th(2)−Cl(4)−Al(2) = 92.6(8)°, Th(2)−Cl(5)−Al(3) = 94.5(7)°]. The fifth equatorial position contains a σ-bonded carbon atom of the deprotonated central phenyl ring of the second ligand system [Th(2)−C(33) = 2.654(14) Å, C(33)−Th(2)−Cl(4) = 78.89(5)°, C(33)−Th(2)−Cl(5) = 78.0(5)°]. Both axial positions of the bipyramid are occupied by two centroids of the two pyrrolide rings of the ligand system [Th(2)−centroid(3) = 2.607(15) Å, Th(2)−centroid(4) = 2.595(14) Å, centroid(3)−Th(2)−centroid(4) = 174.1(5)°, centroid(3)−Th(2)−C(33) = 87.2(5)°, centroid(4)−Th(2)−C(33) = 87.0(5)°, centroid(3)−Th(2)−Cl(1) = 92.2(5)°], which are coordinated to the Th metal center through a η5-interaction. Each nitrogen atom of the pyrrolide ring is σ-bonded to a Et2Al metal center [N(3)−Al(3) = 1.985(15) Å, N(4)−Al(2) = 1.969(15) Å], in turn bridging one equatorial chlorine [Al(2)−Cl(4) = 2.290(18) Å, Al(3)−Cl(5) = 2.290(18) Å, N(3)−Al(3)−Cl(5) = 89.3(8)°, N(4)−Al(2)−Cl(4) = 90.1(8)°].

elements.content: 2b. Overall the molecule of complex 2b possess C 2 symmetry with the 180° rotation axis along the Cl(1)−Th(1)−C(10) vector (Figure ). The two axial positions of the octahedral geometry of the metal are occupied by a chlorine atom [Th(1)−Cl(1) = 2.779(2) Å] and the σ-bonded carbon atom [Th(1)−C(10) = 2.612(8) Å, Cl(1)−Th(1)−C(10) = 180.0°] of the central aromatic ring of the ligand system. The equatorial plane is determined by another chlorine atom [Th(1)−Cl(2) = 2.847(2) Å, Cl(2)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 92.53(4)°] as well as by its symmetry-generated equivalent. These particular chlorine atoms are also involved in a bridging interaction with the two lithium countercations forming Th(1)−Cl(2)−Li(1) = 88.7(3)°. The last two equatorial positions contain the centroids of the two η5-bonded pyrrolide rings [Th(1)−centroid(1) = 2.576(6) Å, centroid(1)−Th(1)−Cl(2) = 89.67(15)°, centroid(1)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 92.03(15)°] (Figure ).

elements.content: 3. The structure of 3 displays an infinite polymeric chain composed of anionic chlorine- and potassium-bridged Th-containing monomers. The negative charge of each anionic Th/K unit is counterbalanced by one unconnected Li cation solvated by three molecules of DME. Each monomeric unit contains the Th metal in the center of an octahedral coordination polyhedron generated by an internal mirror plane of symmetry. One axial position of the coordination polyhedron is occupied by a centroid of five atoms of the former phenyl ring, which appears to be now a [(C(8)−C(10)−C(11)−C(10A)−C(8A)] cyclohexadienide unit [Th(1)−centroid(1) = 2.463(7) Å]. As a result, the ring is severely distorted with the sixth carbon atom pointing away from the plane defined by the other five carbons. The ring C−C bond distances also indicate that the extruded carbon atom forms rather long bonds with the neighboring C atoms, indicative of single-bond character [C(8)−C(9) = 1.526(10) Å]. The second axial position contains one chlorine atom [Th(1)−Cl(1) = 2.764(2) Å, centroid(1)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 85.41(14)°]. Two other symmetry-related chlorine atoms determine two of the four equatorial positions of the coordination octahedron [Th(1)−Cl(2) = 2.735(2) Å, Cl(2)−Th(1)−Cl(2A) = 86.39(9)°]. The potassium cation caps the triangular face of the octahedron as defined by the three facially oriented chlorine atoms [Th(1)−Cl(1)−K(1′) = 88.78(15)°, Th(1)−Cl(2)−K(1′) = 87.91(10)°] (Figure ).

elements.content: 4. Complex 4 shows the Th metal center in an octahedral coordination environment defined by two dipyrrolide ligands. One ligand adopted a rather regular bonding mode, with the two nitrogen atoms of the two pyrrolide rings being σ-coordinated to the Th center in one equatorial and one axial position [Th(1)−N(3) = 2.435(5) Å, Th(1)−N(4) = 2.442(5) Å, N(3)−Th(1)−N(4) = 82.84(16)°]. A second equatorial position is occupied by the centroid of the central phenyl ring of the same ligand, which is π-bonded to the metal center in a regular η6-fashion [Th(1)−centroid(2) = 3.481(7) Å, centroid(2)−Th(1)−N(4) = 74.97(18)°, centroid(2)−Th(1)−N(3) = 77.16(17)°]. The second ligand unit displays a somewhat similar coordination mode. Two nitrogen atoms of the two pyrrolide rings occupy one equatorial and one axial positions, respectively [Th(1)−N(1) = 2.464(5) Å, Th(1)−N(2) = 2.458(5) Å, N(1)−Th(1)−centroid(2) = 92.11(17)°, N(2)−Th(1)−N(4) = 104.81(16)°, N(1)−Th(1)−N(3) = 83.56(17)°, N(2)−Th(1)−N(3) = 95.89(16)°]. The central ring of this second ligand adopted the η5-bonding mode, with the centroid resting in the second axial position of octahedron [Th(1)−centroid(1) = 2.497(7) Å, centroid(1)−Th(1)−N(3) = 170.88(17)°, centroid(1)−Th(1)−N(2) = 92.81(17)°, centroid(1)−Th(1)−N(4) = 97.61(17)°] (Figure ). The uncoordinated C atom is extruded from the plane defined by the other five atoms and forms bonds with the neighboring carbon atom in the normal range for single bonds [C(13)−C(8) = 1.511(9) Å, C(13)−C(12) = 1.500(9) Å].

elements.content: 5. The structure of 5 is formed by one anionic fragment containing both Th and Li metals and one unconnected Li countercation solvated by three solvent DME molecules. The Th metal center is located in the center of a pentagonal bipyramid (Figure ). One axial position is occupied by a chloride [Th(1)−Cl(1) = 2.724(2) Å], which is also bridging the Li cation [Th(1)−Cl(1)−Li(1) = 81.0(4)°]. A second chlorine atom is terminally bonded and resides in one of the equatorial positions [Th(1)−Cl(2) = 2.790(2) Å, Cl(1)−Th(1)−Cl(2) = 86.28(7)°]. Two other equatorial positions are occupied by two σ-bonded nitrogen atoms of two pyrrolide rings of the ligand [Th(1)−N(1) = 2.499(6) Å, Th(1)−N(2) = 2.533(7) Å, N(1)−Th(1)−N(2) = 81.16(19)°, N(1)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 93.06(14)°, N(2)−Th(1)−Cl(2) = 82.58(14)°] and whose central phenyl ring is η6-bonded with the centroid occupying the second axial position [Th(1)−centroid(1) = 2.732(7) Å, centroid(1)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 174.52(15)°, centroid(1)−Th(1)−Cl(2) = 93.54(15)°]. The last two equatorial positions contain two nitrogen atoms of a π-bonded azobenzene unit [Th(1)−N(3) = 2.465(6) Å, Th(1)−N(4) = 2.310(6) Å, N(3)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 81.44(14)°, N(4)−Th(1)−Cl(1) = 84.82(16)°, N(3)−Th(1)−N(1) = 115.25(19)°, N(4)−Th(1)−Cl(2) = 116.28(15)°] and whose N−N distance [N(3)−N(4) = 1.464(8) Å] is as expected for a N−N single bond (Figure ).

The last two equatorial positions contain two nitrogen atoms of a π-bonded azobenzene unit [Th(1)-N(3) = 2.465(6) Å, Th(1)-N(4) = 2.310(6) Å, N(3)-Th(1)-Cl(1) = 81.44(14)°, N(4)-Th(1)-Cl(1) = 84.82(16)°, N(3)-Th(1)-N(1) = 115.25(19)°, N(4)-Th(1)-Cl(2) = 116.28(15)°] and whose N-N distance [N(3)-N(4) = 1.464(8) Å] is as expected for a N-N single bond (Figure ).

elements.content: Deprotonation of the dipyrrole-benzene ligand 1,3-[(2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4} was carried out in diethyl ether with MeLi, affording the corresponding dilithium salt {1,3-[(2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}Li2·(Et2O)0.5 in high yield (89%). The 1H NMR consisted of eight resonances situated in the range 8−1 ppm. The most intense was located at 1.89 ppm and accounted for the 12 protons of the four methyl groups. The ether molecule resonances were visible at 1.22 and 3.46 ppm, while all the other signals appeared in the typical aromatic region. The phenyl ring proton located between the two attachments was visible as a single resonance at 7.92 ppm. The three remaining protons on the central phenyl ring of the ligand gave one multiplet at 7.42 ppm with the expected intensity. The three peaks at 7.36, 6.79, and 6.36 ppm with relative intensity 2:2:2 are attributed to the protons of two pyrrolide-anion rings.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Deprotonation of the dipyrrole-benzene ligand 1,3-[(2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4} was carried out in diethyl ether with MeLi, affording the corresponding dilithium salt {1,3-[(2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}Li2⋅(Et2O)0.5 in high yield (89%). The 1H NMR consisted of eight resonances situated in the range 8-1 ppm. The most intense was located at 1.89 ppm and accounted for the 12 protons of the four methyl groups. The ether molecule resonances were visible at 1.22 and 3.46 ppm, while all the other signals appeared in the typical aromatic region. The phenyl ring proton located between the two attachments was visible as a single resonance at 7.92 ppm. The three remaining protons on the central phenyl ring of the ligand gave one multiplet at 7.42 ppm with the expected intensity. The three peaks at 7.36, 6.79, and 6.36 ppm with relative intensity 2:2:2 are attributed to the protons of two pyrrolide-anion rings.

elements.content: The reaction of ThCl4(DME)2 with the ligand dilithium salt {1,3-[(2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}Li2·(Et2O)0.5 proceeded rapidly with visible color change as well as initial solubilization of all the materials. Complex 1 was isolated in crystalline form and high yield (87%) after workup (Scheme ).

Complex 1 was isolated in crystalline form and high yield (87%) after workup (Scheme ).

</fig>

The ionic structure of complex 1, as revealed by the X-ray structure, showed the expected arrangement, with the pyrrolide rings adopting the σ-bonding mode with thorium and the central aromatic ring capping the metal in an apparent π-interaction. The 1H NMR spectrum was as expected, showing four aromatic ring protons with relative intensity 2:1:1 located at 8.05, 7.87, and 7.77 ppm, respectively. The broad singlet at 7.87 was assigned to the hydrogen at the ring position between the two substituents. The resonances of the pyrrolide ring protons at the α-position were slightly downfield shifted to 7.17 ppm, with the two other resonances located in the normal range at 5.72 and 5.36 ppm, all with the expected intensity ratio. The peak of the four methyl groups experienced a slight upfield shift, appearing at 1.65 ppm. The resonances of DME bonded to lithium were in the normal range at 3.39 and 3.22 ppm.

elements.content: Even in the scenario where the π-interaction between thorium and the phenyl ring visible in complex 1 might be simply a matter of steric constraint rather than the result of a significant chemical interaction, we regarded this arrangement as promising for attempting the preparation of low-valent synthetic equivalents. Our recent work on the uranium chemistry of the 1,3-bis-iminobenzene ligand system, also having a similarly constrained phenyl ring in the bonding range, has shown that the ring hydrogen atom located between the two attachments may be readily deprotonated during the reduction. In turn, this switched the bonding mode from π to σ and affected the stability of the reduced species. To probe the behavior of the ring in the present case, we have attempted the reaction with alkyl aluminum reagents. The basic idea was that initial alkylation at the Th center may be a prelude to ring deprotonation via an internal C−H σ-bond metathesis reaction, in turn switching the ring bonding mode. By the same token, it was also possible that the Al-containing residue might switch the bonding mode of the pyrrolide rings via σ-coordination to the N donor atom, thus providing the metal with additional and more robust π-interactions. This might produce more starting materials suitable for further reduction.

elements.content: The reaction of 1 with 3 equiv of AlEt3 afforded a mixture of two complexes (2a and 2b), which have been readily separated and purified by fractional crystallization (Scheme ). The first complex was formulated as {[{1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}Th(μ-Cl-AlEt2)2](μ-Cl)2[{1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]C6H4}Th](μ-AlEt2)Cl]}·(C7H8)0.5 (2a) on the basis of the X-ray crystal structure. The salient feature of this species, besides the dinuclear structure, is the anticipated deprotonation of the phenyl ring and consequent switching of bonding mode from π to σ. In turn, the pyrrolide rings also have switched bonding mode from σ to π as a result of the retention of the Al residues σ-bonded to the pyrrolide N atoms. The 1H NMR spectrum of 2a in d 8-THF showed only one type of ligand system, indicating symmetrization in solution and formation of only one type of Th complex. All aromatic protons of the phenyl ring as well as two pyrrolide moieties experienced a minor upfield shift. Three signals with the relative intensity of 2:2:2 positioned at 6.30, 5.46, and 5.26 ppm were attributed to the protons of the two pyrrole rings. Two other signals in a higher ppm region at 7.31 and 6.51 ppm with the intensities of 1:2 were assigned to the central phenyl ring of the ligand. Four methyl groups of the ligand produce an intense singlet at 1.35 ppm with the expected relative intensity. The remaining peaks at 1.01 ppm quartets and triplets at 0.14 ppm are attributed to the two ethyl groups of the diethylaluminum units.

The byproduct of the formation of 2a is formulated as {[{1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}ThCl(μ-Cl)2[Li(DME)]2 (2b). Once crystallized, complex 2b displayed rather poor solubility in hydrocarbon solvents such as THF-d 8, thus preventing satisfactory NMR characterization. The feature in common with 2a is the deprotonation of the central phenyl ring and consequent adoption of the σ-bonding mode. The lithium countercations play in this case a role similar to that of Al in 2a, being part of the σ/π switching of the bonding mode of the pyrrolide rings. The retention of the alkali countercation in combination with the switching of the pyrrolide bonding mode was again regarded as a promising feature for the reductions with alkali metals.

elements.content: Unfortunately the reduction of 2a and 2b with a variety of reductants afforded only intractable materials. Therefore, an attempt to probe the ability of this ligand system to support reduced thorium species was made by reacting 1 in THF with metallic potassium. The reaction proceeded slowly until complete consumption of the reductant, affording [{η5-1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}ThK(μ-Cl)3][Li(DME)3] (3) as a very dark purple crystalline material. The structure is closely related to 1, still showing one ligand surrounding a ThCl3 unit. Different from 1 is that one potassium cation is retained as part of the structure in addition to the pre-existing Li(DME)3 countercation (Scheme ). The anticipated deprotonation of the central phenyl ring and switching of pyrrolide bonding mode did not occur in this case. Yet the reduction was successful since simple atom count is indicative of the presence of the first type of non-Cp trivalent thorium species. In further agreement, 3 is paramagnetic, with the NMR spectrum showing very broad and overlapping lines [μeff = 1.23 μB]. The room-temperature EPR spectrum (Figure ) showed only a broad single wave signal centered at g av = 2.0012 of the A band. The lack of hyperfine coupling may be ascribed to a substantial spin−orbit coupling. At lower temperatures (113.2 K) a remarkable line sharpening was observed, but again no hyperfine coupling was detected. Although complex 3 possesses lower symmetry with respect to the Cp and COT paramagnetic Th derivatives, its spectral data are very comparable.

elements.content: The central phenyl ring shows a very substantial deviation from planarity with the carbon atom located between the two pyrrolyl-methyl attachments pointing away from the molecular core. The consequent interruption of ring conjugation causes this C atom to form long bonding distances (in the C−C single-bond range) with the two neighboring carbon atoms. These features strongly suggest that the phenyl ring has been transformed into a radical anion, implying that the thorium metal center in fact preserved the tetravalent state. Also the geometry deformation at that particular carbon atom might be indicative that this particular position carries a substantial localization of spin density. This idea is well substantiated by DFT calculation (see below). Although in a totally different ligand context, the Th atom of 3 shows the same basic feature observed in the other trivalent synthetic equivalents based on cyclooctatetraene and tris-cyclopentadienyl ligand systems where the thorium center is participating in very substantial charge transfer to the π-system of the ligand.

elements.content: When the reduction of 1 was carried out in DME with K/naphthalene, the reaction also resulted in the sudden formation of an intensely purplish-red color, which, however, gradually faded in the range of 24 h at room temperature. A new complex formulated as {η6-1,3-[(2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}Th{μ-η5-1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H5}K(DME)2 (4) was obtained in moderate yield (Scheme ). The formation of 4 is the result of a complex transformation since in the process one thorium center has acquired one additional ligand at the expense of a second unit and whose fate remains unknown. One potassium is also retained in the structure. Of the two ligand systems, one is virtually unchanged, showing the two pyrrolide rings normally σ-bonded and the central phenyl ring π-bonded, as in the case of 1. The second ligand system has instead the central π-bonded phenyl ring showing the same sort of deformation visible in 3. Different from 3 however, the pale color and diamagnetism gave a clear indication of the metal tetravalent state and absence of unpaired electrons. This necessarily implies that the aromatic ring is anionic, which in turn entails the particular carbon atom pointing away from the molecular core to have acquired one additional hydrogen. In other words, during the reduction and subsequent slow reoxidation the central phenyl ring has been transformed into a cyclohexadienyl anion. The 1H NMR is fully supportive of this proposal. The intact ligand system exhibits chemical shifts very similar to those of 1 and of the ligand dilithium salt. Three signals in the aromatic region of the spectrum appearing at 7.45, 7.33, and 7.23 ppm with a relative intensity of 1:2:1 were assigned to the unaltered phenyl ring coordinated to the Th atom. Three resonances at 6.79, 6.48, and 6.40 ppm with an integration of 2:2:2 were assigned to the pyrrolide fragments of the same ligand. Finally one strong peak at 1.80 ppm, which integrated to 12 protons, could be attributed to the methyl protons. The second ligand system shows the resonances of the pyrrolide protons slightly shifted to 6.73, 6.23, and 5.72 ppm as a possible result of the π-coordination to the potassium cation. The methyl groups of this second tris-anionic ligand system are also significantly shifted to 0.43 ppm. The most interesting features are visible for the cyclohexadienly ring. Two resonances with a relative intensity of 1:2 were located at 7.31 and 7.20 ppm, respectively, accounting for the three coplanar H atoms. The ring CH2 group displays two doublets coupled to each other at 3.77 and 2.60 ppm for the endo and exo hydrogen atoms with the expected intensity.

elements.content: Questions arise about the formation of 4. While 3 is the result of an electron transfer from the reductant to the aromatic ring of 1, the formation of 4 implies both a subsequent hydrogen atom abstraction and the acquisition of a second ligand. Recently, it has been observed that a Ti-promoted dinitrogen cleavage afforded radical hydrogen abstraction when the reduction was run in DME. A multiple hydrogen atom abstraction was previously observed during a reduction of a thorium complex also in DME. Therefore, it is tempting to speculate that an eventual higher lability of DME, with respect to undergoing radical attack, might be responsible for the partial hydrogenations when intermediate reduced species possess a significant radical behavior. However, the fact that 3 does not generate 4 upon solubilization in DME suggests that the naphthalene electron transfer agent may also play a role in the reaction.

elements.content: We have observed that reduction of 1 with Li-naphthalenide in DME follows the same trend of color change as during the formation of 4. The immediate color deepening and change observed upon mixing was followed even in this case by a slow color fading. Since attempts to characterize this deeply colored reduced species failed, we have attempted to trap these intermediates via in situ reaction with mild oxidizing agents. The most successful combination was the reduction of 1 in DME by 2 equiv of Li/naphthalene followed by the addition of azobenzene. The reaction afforded the tetravalent and diamagnetic [{η6-1,3-[(η5-2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]2C6H4}Th(μ-η2-PhNNPh)(μ-Cl)(Cl)Li(DME)][Li(DME)3] (5) (Scheme ). NMR data were in complete agreement with this formulation and did not display any particularly significant feature.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch4" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>4</label>
<graphic id="gr4" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="om-2009-00996n_0011.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Complex 5 contains tetravalent thorium and is clearly the result of a two-electron oxidative addition of a transient two-electron-reduced species to azobenzene. Although the two electrons necessary for the reduction of azobenzene might still be provided by the cooperative action of two one-electron -reduced thorium units, at this stage we cannot rule out the possibility that, in DME and by using alkali naphthalene reductants, a transient two-electron-reduced species might be generated.

elements.content: DFT calculations (vide supra) were performed on the heavy-atom crystallographic coordinates of truncated models of the monomeric anionic unit (Scheme ) , with all the C-H distances adjusted to 1.08 Å. The presence of the mirror plane symmetry element in the X-ray crystal structure resulted in a symmetrical distribution of the electron density and equal values for bond orders and charges of the symmetry-related atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Structure of 3 

DFT calculations (vide supra) were performed on the heavy-atom crystallographic coordinates of truncated models of the monomeric anionic unit (Scheme ) , with all the C-H distances adjusted to 1.08 Å. The presence of the mirror plane symmetry element in the X-ray crystal structure resulted in a symmetrical distribution of the electron density and equal values for bond orders and charges of the symmetry-related atoms.

elements.content: Calculations were performed for the doublet state, corresponding to a hypothetical Th(III) f1 metal center, obtaining a computationally stable model in agreement with the charge transfer hypothesis. The singly occupied highest molecular orbital is located mostly on the aromatic ring of the ligand (Scheme ) and is energetically well separated from both HOMO−1 (ΔE = −2.33 eV) and LUMO (ΔE = 1.21 eV).

elements.content: The computational results also clarified the visible ring distortion of 3. Mulliken population analysis (MPA) indicated that the spin density is concentrated mostly on the ring carbon atom above the ring plane (C(24) = 69.8%). Moreover the orbital contribution of this carbon atom to the formation of the molecular orbital is of pure π-character. Such concentration of electron density on one part of the ring leads to the observed distortion of the aromatic fragment and C−C bond elongation. Such distortion is, however, not significant enough to cause complete deconjugation of the rest of the ring. The spin density values (Scheme ) confirm this hypothesis.

elements.content: It should be also noted that despite the strong localization on the ligand system, there is still a minor and yet substantial presence of electron spin density on the Th metal center (13.4%). The contribution of the Th atom to the molecular orbital is mostly in the form of a 7s−5f hybrid. In-depth analysis of the spin density distribution revealed that the second biggest contribution to the HOMO is provided by the p-orbital of the carbon atom in para position to the “radical” carbon with an overall contribution of 16.3% (Figure ).

elements.content: In summary, calculations substantiate the initial assignment of the oxidation state of the thorium center in this species as mainly tetravalent with the ligand playing the role of electron density storage. The presence of an additional electron on the arene delocalized π-orbital results in a ring distortion. These features lead to the change in Th−C(ligand) bond orders illustrated in Scheme , I (red), while the overall charge distribution is depicted in Scheme , II.

elements.content: In this work, we have reported the preparation of the third case of a paramagnetic thorium low-valent synthetic equivalent, which to the best of our knowledge is the first for a non-Cp-based system. Similarly to the case of the other Cp- and COT-based reduced species, the metal engaged in a substantial charge transfer with the ligand aromatic ring. The possibility that other in situ generated species with similar organic radical-type nature may perform hydrogen abstraction reactions from the reaction mixture or perform reduction reactions opens interesting perspectives for the use of this ligand to generate low-valent synthetic equivalents and for further search for unpredictable reactivity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, we have reported the preparation of the third case of a paramagnetic thorium low-valent synthetic equivalent, which to the best of our knowledge is the first for a non-Cp-based system. Similarly to the case of the other Cp- and COT-based reduced species, the metal engaged in a substantial charge transfer with the ligand aromatic ring. The possibility that other in situ generated species with similar organic radical-type nature may perform hydrogen abstraction reactions from the reaction mixture or perform reduction reactions opens interesting perspectives for the use of this ligand to generate low-valent synthetic equivalents and for further search for unpredictable reactivity.

A solution of 1,3-[(2-C4H3N)(CH3)2C]C6H4 (5.00 g, 17.1 mmol) in Et2O (50 mL) was treated dropwise with a solution of MeLi in Et2O (1.6 M, 23 mL, 36.8 mmol). The sudden gas evolution terminated within 15 min from the end of the addition. Stirring was continued at room temperature for an additional 3 h. After that time the volume of the reaction mixture was reduced in vacuo to about 10 mL, and the resulting solution was layered with hexanes (30 mL). The colorless product was obtained as a microcrystalline material, which was separated by filtration, washed with hexanes (5 mL), and dried in vacuo for 6 h (5.19 g, 15.2 mmol, 89%). Anal. Found (calcd) for Li2C22H27N2O0.5: C 77.34 (77.41), H 7.87 (7.97), N 8.19 (8.21). 1H NMR (500 MHz, THF-d 8, 20 °C) δ: 7.92 (1H, ArH), 7.42 (3H, ArH), 7.37 (2H, pyrrole-H), 6.79 (2H, pyrrole-H), 6.36 (2H, pyrrole-H), 3.45 (2H, (CH3CH 2)2O), 1.88 (12H, −CH 3), 1.23 (3H, (CH 3CH2)2O).

Preparation of [η<sup>6</sup>-{1,3-[(2-C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>3</sub>N)(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>C]<sub>2</sub>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>}ThCl<sub>3</sub>][Li(DME)<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

A solution of the ligand dilithium salt (0.45 g, 1.3 mmol) in DME (20 mL) was added to a suspension of ThCl4(DME)2 (0.37 g, 0.7 mmol) in DME (20 mL). The reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h at room temperature and centrifuged to eliminate some insoluble material. The supernatant was concentrated to about 7 mL in vacuo, layered with hexanes (20 mL), and allowed to stand at room temperature for 2 days. Large pale yellow prisms of 1 separated from the solution and were collected and dried under N2 atmosphere (0.52 g, 0.6 mmol, 87%). Anal. Found (calcd) for ThLiC32H52Cl3N2O6: C 42.34 (42.42), H 5.67 (5.78), N 3.05 (3.09). 1H NMR (500 MHz, THF-d 8, 20 °C) δ: 8.05 (2H, ArH), 7.87 (1H, ArH), 7.77 (1H, ArH), 7.17 (2H, pyrrole-H), 5.72 (2H, pyrrole-H), 5.57 (2H, pyrrole-H), 3.39 (18H, DME, −O-CH 3), 3.22 (12H, DME, −CH 2-O), 1.65 (12H, −CH 3).

A solution of AlEt3 (1.1 mL, 1.0 M, 1.1 mmol) in toluene was added dropwise to a suspension of complex 1 (0.20 g, 0.2 mmol) in the same solvent (10 mL). Stirring was continued at room temperature for an additional 6 h, and the insoluble material was separated by centrifugation. The volume of the supernatant was reduced to about 5 mL and allowed to stand at −37 °C for 3 days. Lemon yellow prisms of 2a separated, filtered, washed with cold (−37 °C) hexane (5 mL), and dried under N2 atmosphere (0.094 g, 0.06 mmol, 62%). Anal. Found (calcd) for Th2Al3C55.50H78Cl5N4 (2a): C 43.69 (43.75), H 5.01 (5.16), N 3.65 (3.68). 1H NMR (500 MHz, THF-d 8, 20 °C) δ: 7.31 (1H, Ar-H), 6.51 (2H, Ar-H), 6.30 (2H, pyrrole-H), 5.46 (2H, pyrrole-H), 5.26 (2H, pyrrole-H), 1.35 (12H, −CH 3), 1.01 (4H, Al-CH 2-CH3), 0.14 (6H, Al-CH2-CH 3).

The solid material obtained with the previous centrifugation was dissolved in DME (10 mL) and filtered, and the resulting solution layered with hexane (20 mL). After 3 days small, colorless prisms of 2b separated from the mother liquor, filtered, washed with hexane (5 mL), and dried under N2 atmosphere (0.031 g, 0.04 mmol, 17%). Anal. Found (calcd) for ThLi2C28H42Cl3N2O4 (2b): C 40.79 (40.87), H 5.07 (5.14), N 3.35 (3.40).

Preparation of [{η<sup>5</sup>-1,3-[(η<sup>5</sup>-2-C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>3</sub>N)(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>C]<sub>2</sub>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>}ThK(μ-Cl)<sub>3</sub>][Li(DME)<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>3</bold>)

A solution of 1 (0.35 g, 0.3 mmol) in THF (15 mL) was stirred with metallic potassium (0.03 g, 0.7 mmol) at room temperature for 5 days. When potassium was completely consumed, the resulting dark purple-red solution was centrifuged to eliminate a small amount of insoluble materials. The volume of the liquid was reduced to about 5 mL and layered with hexane (15 mL). Dark purple prisms of 3 formed, which were washed with hexane (5 mL) and dried under N2 atmosphere (0.20 g, 0.2 mmol, 67%). Anal. Found (calcd) for ThKLiC32H52Cl3N2O6: C 40.59 (40.66), H 5.42 (5.55), N 2.83 (2.92). μeff = 1.23 μB

Preparation of {η<sup>6</sup>-1,3-[(2-C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>3</sub>N)(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>C]<sub>2</sub>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>}Th{μ-η<sup>5</sup>-1,3-[(η<sup>5</sup>-2-C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>3</sub>N)(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>C]<sub>2</sub>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>5</sub>}K (DME)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A suspension of 1 (0.62 g, 0.7 mmol) in DME (15 mL) was treated with a freshly prepared solution of K/naphthalene (0.06 g, 1.5 mmol of K with 0.19 g, 1.5 mmol of naphthalene) in the same solvent (10 mL). An immediate color change to dark red-brown was observed upon mixing, and stirring was continued for an additional 4 h at room temperature. Some insoluble material was separated by centrifugation, and the volume of the solution was reduced to about 5 mL by evaporation in vacuo. A slow discoloration of the solution was observed upon standing for 3 days at room temperature, which was accompanied by the appearance of pale pink prisms of 4. The crystalline mass was filtered, washed with hexane (5 mL), and dried under N2 (0.31 g, 0.30 mmol, 42%). Anal. Found (calcd) for ThKC48H65N4O4: C 55.72 (55.80), H 6.24 (6.34), N 5.43 (5.42). 1H NMR (500 MHz, THF-d 8, 20 °C) δ: 7.45 (1H, Ar′H), 7.33 (2H, Ar′H), 7.31 (1H, −CH−(−)), 7.23 (1H, Ar′H), 7.20 (2H, CH −), 6.79 (2H, pyrrole′-H), 6.73 (2H, K-pyrrole-H), 6.48 (2H, pyrrole′-H), 6.40 (2H, pyrrole′-H), 6.23 (2H, K-pyrrole-H), 5.72 (2H, K-pyrrole-H), 3.77 (1H, −CH 2−), 3.34 (12H, DME, O-CH 3), 3.54 (8H, DME, −CH 2-O), 2.60 (1H, −CH 2−), 1.80 (12H, −CH 3), 0.43 (12H, −CH 3).

Preparation of [{η<sup>6</sup>-1,3-[(η<sup>5</sup>-2-C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>3</sub>N)(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>C]<sub>2</sub>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>}Th(μ<italic toggle="yes">-</italic>η<sup>2</sup>-PhNNPh)(μ-Cl)(Cl)Li(DME)][Li (DME)<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>5</bold>)

A suspension of 1 (0.38 g, 0.4 mmol) in DME (10 mL) was treated with a freshly prepared solution of Li/naphthalene (0.006 g, 0.86 mmol of Li and 0.108 g, 0.84 mmol of naphthalene) in the same solvent (10 mL). An immediate color change from pale green to dark blue-red was observed upon mixing, and stirring was continued at room temperature for additional 3 h. A solution of azobenzene (0.08 g, 0.4 mmol) in DME (5 mL) was added dropwise to the reaction mixture, causing a further color change to intense orange. Stirring was continued for one additional hour, after which the insoluble materials were separated by centrifugation. The volume was reduced to about 6 mL in vacuo and the solution layered with hexanes (15 mL). After 3 days brown-orange prisms of 5 were formed. The crystalline mass was filtered, washed with hexane (5 mL), and dried under N2 (0.29 g, 0.25 mmol, 60%). Anal. Found (calcd) for ThLi2C48H72N4O8Cl2: C 50.13 (50.14), H 6.24 (6.31), N 4.81 (4.87). 1H NMR (500 MHz, THF-d 8, 20 °C) δ: 7.50 (1H, Ar′H), 7.36 (1H, ArH), 7.29 (2H, ArH), 7.24 (2H, Ar′H), 7.16 (2H, Ar′H), 7.10 (2H, Ar′H), 6.99 (2H, Ar′H), 6.84 (1H, Ar′H), 6.48 (1H, ArH), 6.76 (2H, pyrrole-H), 6.27 (2H, pyrrole-H), 6.22 (2H, pyrrole-H), 3.48 (24H, DME, O-CH 3), 3.30 (16H, DME, −CH 2-O), 1.74 (12H, −CH 3).
